children.subject:
I'm definitely not tired of hearing your suggestions. They have been very helpful.

I've been looking for a problem to practice matrix multiplication. I'll try it on this one and see how it goes.

Thanks a lot Kate.

(Are you tired of hearing my opinion on these?)

I think you need to approach it like Chain Matrix - the "root" being the length of the string at m_j to m_i and then you have substrings within that (your "subtrees"). The solution you propose doesn't account for the fact that you are given the locations of the m cuts.

history.content:
I tried solving this problem yesterday in my office hours and suggested a subproblem and recurrence definition.

Check it out here(https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HBqJ_vn6Afs) after you have tried to compare your solution.

children.subject:
A couple of observations;
Kate, those additions accord with my thinking; I think the $$m + 1$$ location should be $$n$$, not $$m$$ though, possibly a typo
Murali I think the sum in the recurrence should be $$S[i, j] = \min\limits_{i < k < j}\{S[i, k] + S[k, j] + c_j - c_i\}$$ rather than $$S[i, j] = \min\limits_{i < k < j}\{S[i, k] + S[k, j] + j - i\}$$ as I think $$i, j$$ are the indices not the locations themselves; although maybe that is what you are saying, Kate, when you refer to the root cost.

I'm hoping that the fact that Murali needed some 25 minutes to answer that in office hours, including a few false starts, without covering the details, is a good sign that it would be considered too large of a task for our impending midterm 1 :-D
Yep, typo, and yes, that's what I meant by root cost.

Murali, Thanks for your solution in office hours. I have one question about it, which is that you don't seem to account for the fact that you cannot cut at every i/j within $$1,\dots,n$$. So, if we let $$c_1,c_2,\dots,c_m$$ be the locations of the cuts (and $$c_0 = 0$$ and $$c_{m+1}=n$$), I think we want to vary i and j from 0 to m+1 and have our "root" cost be $$c_j-c_i$$ and our goal be $$S(0,m+1)$$. The other "gotcha" for me was identifying the base case - $$S(i,i+1)=0$$.

history.content:
6.9 is a string cutting problem where a given string of length n is split m times resulting in m+1 pieces. Each cut costs the length of the string being cut. It asks to find the min cost of cutting a string of size n, m times, such that m+1 substrings are produced.

Here is what I got for the answer:

Table:

T(i, k) -> The minimum cost to cut a string of size i, k times, such that k+1 substrings are produced

Recurrence:

$$T(i,k) = \underset{j,z}{min}(T(j,z) + T(i-j,k-z) : 0\leq j \lt i, z \leq z \leq k)$$

The runtime of this recurrence is $$O(n^{2}m^{2})$$. Since a cut would need to have at least one element, m must be less than or equal to n, so the runtime is O(n^4).

Having to find the min over j and z is what is causing the $$O(n^{2}m^{2})$$ runtime. My thinking is that if am cutting a string of length 20 into 15 and 5 and I have 3 cuts left. I could either apply all 3 cuts to the 15 string and its cuts, apply the cuts to the 5 length string or allocate the cuts between the two strings. Thus, I can't see a way to avoid finding the min over j and z.

I'm wondering if my solution looks correct and if the reason I'm applying for finding the min for both j and k is correct?
history.subject: 6.9 String Cutting [Spoiler]
